stages.title: The Ice Cream Debate
stages.description: Can science answer every question? Make your prediction!

activities.scenario:
Two students are arguing in science class:

Emma says: 'Which ice cream tastes better - chocolate or vanilla? Let's do a scientific investigation!'

Jake says: 'That's not a scientific question. We should ask: Which ice cream melts faster at 25¬∞C?'

Their teacher says one of them is right about what makes a question scientific.
activities.question: Who is correct about scientific questions?
options: Emma is right - any question about ice cream can be scientific
Jake is right - only questions with measurable answers are scientific
Both are right - all questions are equally scientific
Neither is right - ice cream isn't a scientific topic
activities.explanation: Jake is correct! Scientific questions must have MEASURABLE, OBJECTIVE answers. 'Which tastes better?' is based on personal opinion (non-testable). 'Which melts faster at 25¬∞C?' can be measured with a timer and thermometer (testable). The topic (ice cream) doesn't matter - what matters is whether you can test it with evidence!

stages.title: Testable vs Non-Testable
stages.description: Discover the pattern that makes questions scientific.

activities.title: The Question Transformer
activities.description: Watch how changing words transforms opinion questions into scientific ones.

controls.name: Question Type
options: Opinion
Scientific

controls.name: Topic
options: Sports Drinks
Paper Towels
Exercise

observables: OPINION version uses words like: best, better, prettiest, should (can't be measured)
SCIENTIFIC version uses measurable outcomes: most, absorbs, increases, time
Same topic, different question structure = testable or non-testable
Pattern: Replace opinion words with measurable variables!
activities.revealPattern:
**THE PATTERN**: Scientific questions have TWO measurable variables:

1. **Independent Variable** (what you CHANGE): brand, angle, duration, temperature
2. **Dependent Variable** (what you MEASURE): absorption, distance, heart rate, time

Formula: 'How does [INDEPENDENT] affect [DEPENDENT]?' or 'Which [INDEPENDENT] has the most [DEPENDENT]?'

‚ùå 'Which is better?' ‚Üí ‚úÖ 'Which absorbs more water?'
‚ùå 'Is it good?' ‚Üí ‚úÖ 'Does it increase heart rate by 20bpm?'
‚ùå 'Should we use it?' ‚Üí ‚úÖ 'Does it reduce bacteria by 50%?'

activities.title: Fix the Science Fair Project
activities.studentWork:
Science Fair Proposal by Alex:

Research Question: 'Are video games bad for you?'

Method: I will ask my friends whether they think video games are harmful. Then I'll write a report about whether video games are good or bad based on what most people said. I expect to prove that video games are definitely bad because my mom always says they are.

Variables: Video games (independent), whether they're bad (dependent)

Conclusion: Based on opinions, video games should be banned.

errors.issue: 'Bad' is undefined and subjective - bad for what? Sleep? Grades? Eyesight? Reaction time?
errors.fix: Make it specific and measurable: 'Does 2 hours of video games affect sleep duration?' or 'How do video games affect reaction time?'

errors.issue: Collecting OPINIONS, not measurable data. This is a survey of beliefs, not a scientific investigation.
errors.fix: Measure actual outcomes: test reaction time, measure sleep hours, or record attention span with scientific instruments.

errors.location: 'prove that video games are definitely bad'
errors.issue: Starting with a conclusion (confirmation bias) instead of testing objectively.
errors.fix: Start neutral: 'I will investigate whether...' Let the EVIDENCE determine the answer, not your opinion beforehand.

errors.issue: 'Bad' is not measurable. You can't put 'badness' on a scale or timer.
errors.fix: Use measurable dependent variables: hours of sleep, reaction time in milliseconds, test scores, etc.

stages.title: The SMART Question Formula
stages.description: Master the formula for writing testable questions.

activities.title: Testable Question Framework

TESTABLE QUESTIONS.Definition: Questions that can be answered through MEASUREMENT and OBSERVATION (not opinions)
Required Elements: Both variables must be OBJECTIVE (everyone gets the same result)
Examples: ‚úì How does temperature affect dissolving time? (temp = independent, time = dependent)
‚úì Which material absorbs the most water? (material = independent, absorption = dependent)
‚úì Does exercise increase heart rate? (exercise = independent, heart rate = dependent)

NON-TESTABLE QUESTIONS.Definition: Questions based on OPINION, BELIEF, or VALUES (no objective measurement possible)
NON-TESTABLE QUESTIONS.Why They Fail: Different people have different valid answers. No measurement can settle the debate.
Examples: ‚úó Which color is prettiest? (beauty = opinion, can't measure)
‚úó Should we use solar power? (should = value judgment, not testable)
‚úó What's the best music? (best = personal preference)

HOW TO FIX NON-TESTABLE QUESTIONS.Strategy: Replace opinion words with MEASURABLE outcomes
Examples: ‚úó 'Which is the best insulator?' ‚Üí ‚úÖ 'Which material keeps water warmest after 30 minutes?'
‚úó 'Are organic foods better?' ‚Üí ‚úÖ 'Do organic vegetables contain more Vitamin C per 100g?'
‚úó 'Is running good exercise?' ‚Üí ‚úÖ 'Does running increase heart rate more than walking?'
‚úó 'Which tastes better?' ‚Üí ‚úÖ 'Which drink contains the most sugar per 100mL?'

structure.WHY THIS MATTERS:
Science requires EVIDENCE, not opinions. Testable questions let us:
‚Ä¢ Verify findings (others can repeat your test)
‚Ä¢ Build reliable knowledge (facts, not beliefs)
‚Ä¢ Solve real problems (measure what works)
‚Ä¢ Avoid bias (let evidence decide, not opinions)

activities.studentTask: Copy this framework into your science book. For each section, add ONE example of your own that relates to your interests (sports, food, technology, etc.)

stages.title: Question Writing Challenge
stages.description: Apply the formula to create and fix scientific questions.

tiers.scenario: A student asks: 'Which smartphone is the best?'
tiers.question: What's the problem with this question?
options: Smartphones aren't scientific
'Best' is undefined - best at what? Battery life? Camera quality? Speed?
The question is too short
Nothing - it's perfect for science

feedback.correct: Exactly! 'Best' could mean best battery, best camera, best price, etc. You need to specify WHAT you're measuring!

0.issue: Thinking the topic makes a question scientific or not
0.hint: ANY topic can be scientific if you ask about measurable variables. Smartphones have battery life, screen brightness, speed - all measurable!

2.hint: Question length doesn't matter. 'Which is best?' is short but vague. 'Which smartphone has the longest battery life?' is longer but CLEAR and testable.

3.hint: 'Best' is an OPINION word. Different people define 'best' differently. Science needs specific, measurable outcomes everyone can agree on.

tiers.scenario: Your friend wants to investigate: 'Should schools ban junk food?' They're passionate about healthy eating but struggling to design an experiment.
tiers.question: What's the best advice to help them create a testable question?
options: Tell them to give up - 'should' questions can't be turned into science
Keep the question the same and just survey people's opinions
Transform it: 'Does eating junk food before a test affect test scores?' or 'How does junk food consumption correlate with absence rates?'
Change the topic entirely - food isn't scientific

feedback.correct: Perfect! You kept their passion for the topic but made it TESTABLE. Now they can measure test scores or absence rates - real data instead of opinions!

0.issue: Giving up on a topic instead of reformulating the question
0.hint: EVERY interesting topic can become scientific! Just change the QUESTION format to focus on measurable outcomes, not values ('should').

1.issue: Thinking surveys of opinion equal scientific investigation
1.hint: Surveys collect OPINIONS, not scientific evidence. You need to MEASURE actual outcomes (test scores, health metrics, etc.), not ask what people THINK.

3.hint: Food science is HUGE! Nutrition, chemistry, biology - it's all measurable. ANY topic can be scientific if you focus on measurable variables.

tiers.scenario:
You're designing a science fair project about climate change. You draft this question: 'How has average rainfall changed in our region over the past 50 years?'

Your teacher says: 'That's a good factual question, but it's not really an INVESTIGATIVE question for a science fair. What could you investigate that goes beyond just looking up data?'
tiers.question: How can you improve this to make it a stronger investigative question?
options: Keep it the same - it's already perfect
Change to: 'Is climate change bad?' to make it more relevant
Improve to: 'Does increased rainfall correlate with changes in local plant species diversity?' or 'How does rainfall variation affect crop yield in our region?'
Give up on climate - it's too controversial for science

feedback.correct: Outstanding! You've transformed a data-lookup question into true INVESTIGATION. Now you'll collect data, analyze relationships, and discover something new - that's real science!

0.issue: Not distinguishing between factual questions and investigative questions
0.hint: Factual questions have KNOWN answers you look up. Investigative questions require you to COLLECT DATA and ANALYZE relationships. Science fairs want you to discover new insights!

1.issue: Adding opinion words to make questions 'better'
1.hint: 'Bad' is an opinion word that makes questions WORSE, not better. Science investigates WHAT HAPPENS (effects, relationships), not WHETHER we should care (values).

3.issue: Avoiding topics due to controversy instead of using science to investigate them
3.hint: Controversial topics are PERFECT for science! Use measurable data to move beyond opinions. Climate science investigates temperatures, rainfall, sea levels - all measurable facts.

stages.title: Question Mastery
stages.description: Reflect on your question-writing skills and reveal the prediction.

criteria.S: I can consistently write testable questions with clear variables AND help others fix their non-testable questions. I understand why testable questions are crucial for scientific progress and can apply this to any topic.
criteria.A: I can reliably identify testable vs non-testable questions and write good testable questions using the formula. I can fix most non-testable questions by replacing opinion words with measurable variables.
criteria.B: I understand the difference between testable and non-testable questions. I can usually identify opinion words and know the question formula, but sometimes struggle to apply it to new situations.
criteria.C: I know testable questions need measurable variables, but I often use opinion words without realizing it. I can recognize the formula but need practice applying it consistently.
criteria.D: I'm still learning to spot the difference. I sometimes confuse opinion questions with testable ones and need to review the red flag words and question formats.
criteria.F: I don't yet understand what makes a question testable. I need to review the core concepts about variables and measurement.

activities.reflection: Think about a topic you're genuinely curious about (sports, music, gaming, cooking, etc.). Write one NON-testable question about it, then transform it into a testable question using the formula. Explain what you changed and why.

activities.title: üéØ Prediction Reveal: The Ice Cream Question
activities.content:
**Remember the debate from the start?**

Emma: 'Which ice cream tastes better - chocolate or vanilla?'
Jake: 'Which ice cream melts faster at 25¬∞C?'

**Why Jake was RIGHT:**

‚ùå **Emma's Question (Non-Testable)**:
‚Ä¢ 'Tastes better' = OPINION (my favorite ‚â† your favorite)
‚Ä¢ No measurement possible
‚Ä¢ Can't be settled with evidence
‚Ä¢ Different people = different valid answers

‚úÖ **Jake's Question (Testable)**:
‚Ä¢ 'Melts faster' = MEASURABLE (use timer + thermometer)
‚Ä¢ Clear variables: ice cream type (independent), melting time (dependent), temperature (controlled at 25¬∞C)
‚Ä¢ Everyone doing the test gets similar results
‚Ä¢ Evidence-based answer

**The Key Insight:**
The TOPIC (ice cream) doesn't determine if a question is scientific. The QUESTION STRUCTURE does!

You can ask non-scientific questions about 'sciencey' topics:
‚ùå 'Which element is the coolest?' (opinion about science)

You can ask scientific questions about 'everyday' topics:
‚úÖ 'Which cookie recipe produces the crispiest texture?' (measurable food science)

**What Makes a Question Scientific:**
1. Has measurable variables
2. Can be tested with evidence
3. Others can verify your results
4. Not based on opinion or values

Now you can transform ANY curiosity into a scientific investigation! üî¨
